721280f-a.title: Manhattan: Madison Avenue - 37th Street (East)
721280f-a.text:
240 Madison Avenue, west side, between 37th and 38th Streets.
This building was demolished about the middle of the 1920's,
and replaced by a taller building. Next door the old Hechsher
Building is nearing completion.
1916.

721277f-a.title: Manhattan: Madison Avenue - 37th Street (East)
721277f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, south from East 37th Street. At the
left margin is the old J. P. Morgan residence. This was
demolished for the present Library. Beyond are two brown
stone houses that were subsequently replaced by an apart-
ment building. The two story garage, the Tudoric ''Percy
Silver' residence, and the Church of the Incarnation re-
main. The row below, adjoining the dominant Cameron Build-
ing were replaced (in 1939) by the 14 story Goodhue House.
Onposite same is the marble B. Altman Lepartment Store.
Gutlined against the lower part of this building is a row
of residences that were removed for the dom'ustion Engineer-
ing Building. Closer to the camera is a more individual
row. lans for an apartment house here were sdvnnced in
June of 1940. In the background, at the beginning of this
thoroughfare is the dimly outlined Metropolitan tower.
May 18, 1924
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of kanhattan
CREDIT LINE iEPERATIVE

721281f-a.title: Manhattan: Madison Avenue - 37th Street (East)
721281f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from 38th to 37th Streets, showing the
Fraternity Clubs Building, 22 East 38th Street, built by the
Allerton House interests about 1923, on the lot formerly occupied
by South Church (Dutch Reformed). In the middle of the block is
the Hotel Duane, about contemporary with it, occupying the site of
237-239 Madison Avenue, the two old four-story houses which used to
stand there. On the N.E. corner of 37th Street is the old Delmar
Mansion, which has been occupied since 1923 by the National
Democratic Club.
About 1927.
(hnderwood \& Underwood.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

June 6, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
